COMMENTS

My cousin Bryan (Fisher) passed me an album late at night at a party is Stevenage, I was 14. He said you must listen to this its totally amazing - it was Fresh Cream. The rest is history - Jack was just incredible, that voice combined with those flying basslines and beautiful harp. It set a corner stone for my life thats never dimmed -- so so sad - been playing Cream vinyl and Jacks great subsequent albums since Saturday night --- Graham (Everson)

NAME: Janie Morris

LOCATION: South Africa

Email: jane_henstock

[at]: neomail

[dot]: co.za

Date: 27 Oct 2014

Time: 09:55:04

COMMENTS

Dear Jack, I'm a wee bit numb still-I cannot take in that your fingers won't find the strings or the keys anymore...that you won't feel that utter love you had for making music again. Each note you played was special as it was exactly as you wished it to be....one, as gentle as your vulnerable soul, another as bold as the streets of Glasgow, yet another as passionate as your affair with the Blues,...music so honest & truthful that it sounds like NOTHING else. I heard the sexy Blues, I heard tantilising Jazz, I heard that Scots spirit, I heard the grandure of the classical composers....I feel that I know you personally because you really DID laid your soul bare in your music! Jack, you DID it - you made music your career, you played every conceivable genre....but you came "home" on Silver Rails. Then you were able to go. Thanks for making the ONLY music that conquered my heart and soul. God Bless You and God Bless Your Family as they will surely have broken hearts that will need mending. Wee Janie in South Africa

I was a fan of Jack's since the 60s and as a semi pro singer, songwriter,guitarist, he was a great influence. His talent will be sorely missed and at the next meeting of the local acoustic music club, I'll be performing "Theme For An Imaginary Western" as my own little tribute. As I'm from Sudbury, I saw Jack a few times around town, but always thought he could do without me pestering him and stopping him getting on with his life. I'm just grateful to have been part of a generation that could hear Jack's music and look forward to seeing the inevitable BBC tribute. R.I.P. Jack

I am quite saddened on this Monday morning after I found out that one of my musical idols has passed away two days ago. I have been playing bass guitar since 2009 and Cream is one of my all-time favorite bands mainly because of Jack's lead vocals and melodic bass (I was born in the 1990s by the way). His Gibson EB-3 has a distinct tone that is very difficult to reproduce on another bass and apply in various musical settings. This is what made Jack and his style very unique. Jack was one of my heroes and a true inspiration when writing bass solos and playing with or without a band. His work inspired me to be more aggressive with my bass and musical style, giving me ideas to bring the bass into the forefront. I truly thank him for his inspiration, influence, and for everything that he has done for the world of music. Rest In Peace Jack. You will be missed.

I'm a friend of Kofi and Malcolm's. Malcolm had been doing some shows with us when I went out with my son to hear Son's of Cream. To our surprise, Jack walked in. Of course he went straight to the bar. We were having drinks together. He was VERY gracious to the few fans who recognized him. I enjoyed hanging with one of my heros, just having drinks like a regular guy at the bar. Needless to say, he had had a few! At break, Malcolm comes up to me and says "My dad wants to play, what should I do?" (I think he was worried that he had been drinking a bit...) To which I said, "Your dad is Jack Bruce, you HAVE to let him play." My son and I were standing 3 feet from Jack in a small club when second set opened with Spoonful. Jack was beyond great. It was an experience I'll never forget and a moment with my son, Eric, that we will both treasure forever. BTW, Eric was a student of Kofi's. He went on to achieve a Masters Degree in Jazz Drum Set and became one of the best drummers I know!

Jack Bruce, The great bass player, composer and singer of the Legend of Cream passed away. I will always remember the first time that I listened CREAM: I was in love immediately. I was a little boy and one day, in my old house, in which I was born, I found an audio cassette and decided tio play it. I was so inpressed by White Room, Crossroads, Politician, Born under a bad sign, Sunshine of your love, Tales of brave Ulysses, all really wonderful songs. That way to sing so free and outside the rules and that way to play the bass guitar of Jack Bruce, so powerful and original accompanied by the tribal rhythm of Ginger Baker, so incredible. The sound of the guitar of Eric Clapton...so amazing, quicksilver! Crossroads, Spoonful...a new way to feel and play the blues. I didn't know who left that audio cassette in my house...it's a mistery even now! It seemed the destiny...to know and love Cream!!!! And then, after a long time, I received the gift of a new record: "Around the next dream" (B.B.M.). I was so curious and happy to listen that sound again, except Gary Moore in place of Eric Clapton. And in 2005, the Reunion! The desire not realized to go to London to embrace and see my heroes to the Royal Albert Hall, that incredible happiness to buy the dvd, go home and enjoy every second, note, frame. And then, I formed my actual band, Mr.Cream, the tribute to the legend of CREAM! I'm very proud to sing and play this music and have the way to remember and show Cream to the people that come to my gigs. Thank you Jack pfor everything you gave and left to us in all these years. A big big hug everywhere you are. I will always remember you with all my heart like you composed, sang and play with all your heart :-) Sincerely yours, Luca Vaglica
